journal-meta.journal-title: Margin: The Journal of Applied Economic Research

title-group.article-title: Market Power in the Log and Lumber Import Market in Japan

contrib.aff: Tsaiyu Chang (corresponding author) is Project Research Fellow at the Asian Natural Environmental Science Center of The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, email: tsaiyu@anesc.u-tokyo.ac.jp
Masafumi Inoue is Associate Professor at the Asian Natural Environmental Science Center of The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan, email: masafumi@anesc.u-tokyo.ac.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 National Council of Applied Economic Research
permissions.copyright-holder: National Council of Applied Economic Research

abstract.p: Japan imports rather than exports forestry products even though it has ample forestry resources. Moreover, the leading exporters of forest products often have strong market power in the trade market of forestry products. The possibility of incomplete competition in the Japanese wood import market can also be suspected from the fact that the structure of imports of logs and lumber has remained unchanged over the past 10 years. However, there has been limited empirical economic analysis of the timber trade market to support this assertion.

In this study, we examine the market power of the primary exporting countries in the Japanese log and lumber market based on the residual demand model. We analysed the import data of forestry products from 1988 to 2010 with respect to every main item exported to Japan. The analysis shows that Canada has market power over several items of logs in the Japanese import market, while the United States and Canada have market power over several items of lumber. The study also clarifies that imperfect competition exists in the Japanese timber import market and that the timber price in Japan is partially determined by the exporting countries.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Japan is a net importer of forestry products, even though it is endowed with ample forestry resources. Moreover, the major exporters of forest products often exhibit demand oligopoly in the factor market and supply oligopoly in the product market, which indicates their strong market power in the trade market. The structure of imports of logs and lumber has remained unchanged over the past 10 years, which also suggests the possibility of incomplete competition in the Japanese wood import market. However, previous studies that analyse the market power in the timber trade market have been limited.

In this study, we analyse the structure of the Japanese log and lumber market in order to investigate the market power of the primary exporting countries. We applied the residual demand model to analyse the import data of forestry products from 1988 to 2010 with respect to every main item exported to Japan.

sec.title: THE JAPANESE LOG AND LUMBER MARKET
sec.p: Many studies have indicated the monopolistic structure of wood procurement in the world. For example, most of the lumber in the United States (US) is produced by large companies (Murashima and Araya, 2000), and 70 per cent of Canadian forest resources are state-owned and managed by the forest tenure and licensing system. Canada’s forest tenure system, that ensures companies’ investment as opposed to a competitive bidding system, is considered to have set a cheap stumpage fee to attract businesses (Murashima and Araya, 2000; Pratt and Urquhart, 1994), which was responsible for the Canada–US softwood lumber dispute. Peter (2007) also insists that Canadian wood products have market power in East Asia, especially in Japan. In South Africa, New Zealand and Chile, about 40 per cent of artificial forest resources are controlled by large corporate groups (Murashima and Araya, 2000). In Russia, forests are state-owned and leased to logging companies for timber harvest through contracts for up to 49 years. Although the timber auction system is more efficient and becoming popular in Russia, the prevalent system of flat stumpage fees typically values Russian wood at 10 per cent of European prices (Mayer et al., 2005). Furthermore, although production and transportation costs are higher in European countries, these countries are still expanding their share of the Japanese lumber market. One reason for this is that European countries succeeded in meeting the changing needs of end-users in the Japanese market (Owari, 2004).

Considering all the various factors together, we can reasonably speculate that an oligopolistic structure may exist in the international wood trade market. Shimamoto (2010) indicates that the leading exporters of forestry products often exhibit demand oligopoly in the factor market and supply oligopolyin the product market. Hence, a change in the amount produced in some industries affects the price in importing countries, which means these oligopolistic companies may have strong market power in the trade market. However, further empirical analysis is required to verify this assertion.

We also review the structure of the Japanese wood import market to consider the status of the oligopoly. Figure 1 presents the composition of the Japanese log import market from 1999 to 2009. Although total log imports decreased, the main exporting countries have remained almost the same, with the proportion of imports from Russia decreasing more than other countries. In contrast, the proportion of imports from the US and Canada increased from 24 per cent and 5 per cent to 40 per cent and 18 per cent, respectively. The market share of New Zealand and Malaysia is approximately 10 per cent each. Figure 2 presents the composition in the Japanese lumber import market from 1999 to 2009. We can see that the proportion of imports from Canada decreased from 47 per cent to 35 per cent, while the proportion of imports from European countries increased from 19 per cent to 36 per cent. Russia, the US and Chile have a relatively small market share. However, as for log imports, although total lumber imports decreased, the main exporting countries have remained largely unchanged.

caption.title: Composition of the Japanese Log Import Market
caption.p: Source: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Japan (20123).

caption.title: Composition of the Japanese Lumber Import Market
caption.p: Source: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in Japan (20123).

sec.title: THEORETICAL FOUNDATIONS
sec.p: In this section, we present the theoretical foundations of the market structure of forestry products in Japan. We use the residual demand-estimation model to explore market power. We measure the relationship between an industry’s price and quantity while the reactions by other industries are given. Baker and Bresnahan (1988) first proposed to use residual demand elasticity to estimate market power. Goldberg and Knetter (1999) applied this approach to international market competition among exporting companies. They measured the market power of German beer and US linerboard in specific destination markets. Other studies focused on the competitiveness of the Japanese import market. For example, Reed and Saghaian (2004) used a similar approach to estimate the price elasticity of beef demand in the Japanese import market. Based on the same framework, Felt et al. (2011) implemented a generalised method of moments procedure to estimate the inverse residual demand elasticities of the three largest exporters to the Japanese pork market, namely, the US, Canada and Denmark.

Consider a simple market structure consisting of two countries that export to the Japanese market. The inverse demand function in the Japanese market for exporting country i is:
(1) pi = Di(Qi, pj, Z); i≠j

where i, j denote the two different exporting countries, pi is the import price from country i, Qi is the total quantity imported from country i, and Z is a vector of exogenous variables that affect Japan’s demand.

The profit maximisation problem for exporting country i can be written as:
(2) πi = piQi – eiCi(Qi) = Di(Qi, pj, Z)Qi – eiCi(Qi)
where πi is the profit of the export country, ei is the bilateral exchange rate between Japan and the exporting country, and Ci is the cost of the product.

Assuming that pi satisfies the sufficient conditions for differentiability, the first-order condition for profit maximisation is to set the marginal revenue equal to marginal cost, which is
(3) pi+Qi∂pi∂Qi(1+∂Di∂pj∂Dj∂pi) – eiMCi=0
where MCi is the marginal cost in the exporter’s currency.

Here, the terms in brackets represent the conduct parameters of exporting country i, faced with other competitors, and the strategic interactions of the exporters in the market. In the case of perfect competition, the terms in brackets are zero. If these terms are not zero, they could provide a measure of market power through the inverse demand relationships and the corresponding first-order conditions (Baker and Bresnahan, 1988).1

Goldberg and Knetter (1999) manipulate the system of equations defined in the given equations and obtain a single equation to estimate the exporter’s residual demand. They use the first-order condition in Equation (3) and the inverse demand in Equation (1) to write the export price as p*i(Qj, eiWi, Z; θi). Here, Wi denotes the union of all firm-specific cost shifters, such as input price, and Z denotes the union of demand shifters (for example, the income of the importing country and the time trend); and p*i represents a partial reduced form of the export price. In this case, the only endogenous variable appearing on the right-hand side is Qj.

Substituting this expression into the inverse demand for the product of country j yields pj = Dj(Qj, p*i(Qj, eiWi, Z; θi), Z) = Dj,residual (Qj, eiWi, Z; θi). Thus, the residual demand curve has three observable arguments: the quantity produced by the exporter; demand shifters; and cost shifters of other firms. The residual demand elasticity is:
hj=∂lnDj,residual∂lnQj=∂lnDj∂lnQj+∂lnDj∂lnp*i∂lnp*i∂lnQj
The derivatives ∂lnp*i∂lnQj correspond here to the actual responses of competitor prices to a change in the exporting group’s quantity.

The explicit expression of the inverse residual demand function for an exporter who faces N competitors in the market, as developed by Goldberg and Knetter (1999) is:
(4) lnpt, ki=αk+ηkilnQt, ki+βk′lnWt, kN+γk′lnZt, k+εt, ki N=1...n

where k denotes a specific destination market, t denotes time, and εt,ki is an independent and identically distributed error term. Greek letters denote parameters. The parameter ηk can be directly interpreted as the residual demand elasticity. An estimate of zero indicates perfect competition and a lack of market power. A statistically significant value of ηk< 0 means there is market power, and larger absolute values of ηk indicate larger deviations from marginal cost pricing and more power in the export market.

sec.title: THE EMPIRICAL MODEL AND DATA
sec.p: It is assumed that each country exporting logs and lumber faces a residual demand, reflected as overall Japanese demand less the supply from other competitors. Moreover, each country exports different types of log and lumber. The Japanese market is segmented by log types and lumber types. Our measurement targets are softwood logs, other logs, lumber and lauan. Softwood logs include Sitka spruce, abies and picea, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir; and lumber includes Sitka spruce, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir.

In the estimates, we use Japanese real gross domestic product (GDP) as the demand shifter, and the index of input price and bilateral exchange rate as the competitors’ cost shifters. Hence, the empirical model is as follows:
(5) lnpt, ki=αk+ηkilnqt, ki+β1, klnWt, kN+β2, kln ext, kN+γklnYt, kJP+εt, ki N=1...n

where k denotes a specific destination market; t denotes a time trend; i denotes an exporting country; p is the price of the product in the importing country; q is the total quantity of exports; N denotes the competing countries; εt,ki is an independent and identically distributed error term; w denotes an index of the input price; ex denotes the bilateral exchange rate; Y denotes the real GDP in Japan; and Greek letters denote parameters.

Equation (5) is estimated for each log and lumber type separately. We have treated the equations for each country and for each product type as a separate simultaneous system using the iterative seemingly unrelated regression (SUR). Hence, there is a simultaneous system for each log type (Sitka spruce, abies and picea, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir), each lumber type (Sitka spruce, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir) and lauan. For example, there are three main competitors in the white cedar and yellow cedar log market in Japan, namely, the US, Canada and Russia. Hence, we estimate the simultaneous system with three country equations using the iterative SUR.

The model is applied for yearly data from February 1988 to 2010. The trade data are from the Japanese Ministry of Finance. Log (wood in the rough) is defined by the four-digit HS code, 4403, and includes Sitka spruce, abies and picea, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock, Douglas fir, lauans and apitons. Lumber (wood, shaped or simply worked) is defined by the four-digit HS code 4407, and includes Sitka spruce, white cedar and yellow cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir. The import prices are proxied by the import unit price, obtained from the trade data of import values and quantities. The data of cost shifters and demand shifters are obtained from the dataset of World Databank. One cost shifter is the wholesale price index (WPI) (2005 = 100). Another cost shifter is the bilateral exchange rate. The bilateral exchange rate is obtained by dividing the official exchange rate in Japan (per USD) by the official exchange rate in the exporting country (per USD). The bilateral exchange rate between the Japanese yen and the euro is obtained from the Research and Statistics Department, Bank of Japan. Finally, the data for the demand shifter, the real GDP in Japan, are calculated based on the ratio of the nominal GDP to the consumer price index.

sec.title: ESTIMATION AND RESULTS
sec.p: We estimate residual demand in the main exporting countries for each type of log and lumber product separately. The exporting countries exported the specified products contiguously between 1988 and 2010. Equation (5) of the simultaneous system with all competitors is estimated using the iterative SUR. There is a simultaneous system for seven log types and four lumber types. Each simultaneous system has two to four equations, depending on the number of the exporting countries. Overall, there are 17 equations for the log market and nine equations for lumber market and accordingly, 26 residual (inverse) demand elasticities.

Table 1 and Table 2 summarise the estimation results for the Japanese log market and lumber market, respectively. The coefficients of interest are the estimates of the inverse residual demand elasticities, which are shown in the first row. In Table 1, the estimated inverse residual demand elasticities of hemlock and Douglas fir of Canada, have the expected negative sign and are statistically different from zero (shown as bold text). This implies that Canada is not a price taker in Japanese log market. This evidence suggests that log exporters in Canada have some market power in the Japanese market. Besides, although most of the cost shifters and demand shifters are not significant, the cost shifter, WPI of the US, is positive and significant in the equation of the Douglas fir of Canada. This implies that the market power of Canada is partially constrained by the US. Also, the demand shifter, real GDP in Japan, is positive and significant in the equation of the Douglas fir of Canada, which implies that the import price from Canada is positively affected by the Japanese market scale. Moreover, the estimated inverse residual elasticity of other logs from Russia is negative and statistically different from zero, suggesting that Russia has a degree of market power in the Japanese log market.

caption.p: The Estimation Results for the Japanese Log Market (dependent variable: log price [in Japan yen] of log [wood in the rough] imports)

tr.td: Dependent Variable: Log Price of Log (wood in the rough) Imports, which is ln (import price of the log type from the exporting country)
Import quantity from the exporting country (residual demand elasticities)

table-wrap-foot.p: (iii) a, b, c and d denote significance at the 1 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 15 per cent level, respectively.
(iv) US denotes United States; CA denotes Canada; RU denotes Russia; NZ denotes New Zealand; and MY denotes Malaysia.
(v) The Durbin–Watson d-statistic and Breusch–Godfrey LM tests are estimated by ordinary least squares (OLS). The null hypothesis of the Breusch–Godfrey LM test is H0: no serial correlation.

sec.p: With regard to the Japanese lumber market, shown in Table 2, the estimated residual inverse demand elasticity of Sitka spruce of the US, and Douglas fir of the US are significantly different from zero at the 1 per cent and 15 per cent levels.2

caption.p: Estimation Results for the Japanese Lumber Market (dependent variable: log price [in Japan yen] of log [wood in the rough] imports)

tr.td: Dependent Variable: Log Price of Lumber Imports, which is ln(import price of the lumber type from the exporting country)
Import quantity from the exporting country

table-wrap-foot.p: (iii) a, b, c and d denote significance at the 1 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 15 per cent level, respectively.
(iv) US denotes United States and CA denotes Canada.
(v) The Durbin–Watson d-statistic and Breusch–Godfrey LM test are estimated by OLS. The null hypothesis of Breusch–Godfrey LM test is H0: no serial correlation.

sec.p: The Breusch–Godfrey and Durbin–Watson tests are applied in order to test for serial correlation. The null hypothesis of the Breusch–Godfrey test is that there is no serial correlation. The estimation procedure is done by ordinary least squares (OLS) and the results are shown in the last three rows in Table 1 and Table 2. From the Breusch–Godfrey tests at the 15 per cent significance level, we find that nine of the 17 equations have serial correlations in Table 1, and two of the nine equations have serial correlation in Table 2. Though the serial correlation problem might not be serious, the OLS may suffer from incorrect standard errors. To solve this problem, we employ the Cochrane–Orcutt procedure, which transforms both the dependent and independent variables by quasi-differencing before estimating. The results are shown in Table 3 and Table 4.

caption.p: Estimation Results for the Japanese Log Market (dependent variable: time difference of log price [in Japan yen] of log [wood in the rough] imports)

tr.td: Dependent Variable: Time Difference of Log Price of Log (wood in the rough) Imports,which is ln([import price of the log type from the exporting country]t – [import price of the log type from the exporting country]t–1)
Import quantity from the exporting country

table-wrap-foot.p: (iii) a, b, c and d denote significance at the 1 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 15 per cent level, respectively.
(iv) US denotes United States, CA denotes Canada, RU denotes Russia, NZ denotes New Zealand and MY denotes Malaysia.

sec.p: In Table 3, the estimated inverse residual demand elasticity of Sitka spruce from Canada has the expected negative sign and become statistically different from zero at the 15 per cent significance level. The results in Table 3 show that Canada has market power for more types of log in the Japanese market than the results in Table 1. Both Table 1 and Table 3 show the estimated inverse residual demand elasticity of hemlock from Canada and Douglas fir from Canada have the expected negative sign and become statistically different from zero. This suggests that Canada log exporters have market power in some Japanese log import markets.This suggests that lumber exporters have market power in most Japanese lumber import markets, other than those of white cedar and yellow cedar.

caption.p: Estimation Results for the Japanese Lumber Market (dependent variable: time difference of log price [in Japan yen] of lumber imports)

tr.td: Dependent Variable: Time Difference of Log Price of Lumber (wood in the rough) Imports, which is ln([import price of the lumber type from the exporting country]t – [import price of the lumber type from the exporting country]t–1)
Import quantity from the exporting country

table-wrap-foot.p: (iii) a, b, c and d denote significance at the 1 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 15 per cent level, respectively.
(iv) US denotes United States and CA denotes Canada.

sec.p: In Table 4, the estimated elasticity of Sitka spruce from the US, hemlock from the US, and Douglas fir from the US and Canada is significantly different from zero at the 1 per cent level. The results in Table 4 show that the US and Canada have market power for more types of lumber in the Japanese market than the results in Table 2.3

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: On the basis of our estimates, it is clear that Canada has market power on several kinds of logs in the Japanese import market. With regard to the lumber market, the estimates show that the US and Canada have market power on some import items. The study clarified that imperfect competition exists in the Japanese timber import market and that Japanese timber price levels can partially be determined by the exporting countries.

Most of our discussion assumes a competitive trade structure when discussing free trade. However, when the forestry or forest industry in the exporting countries is oligopolistic, the markets of the importing countries may also be subject to monopoly. Therefore, the policy implication of this study is to effectively and fairly address these issues in trade negotiations with exporting countries so as to increase the competitiveness and improve the domestic timber industry in Japan.

fn.p:
In an imperfectly competitive market, the extent of competition is expressed as the relative markup of price over marginal cost, or the Lerner index. Here, the Lerner index is:
Li=pi–eiMCipi=–(Qipi∂pi∂Qi)(1+∂Di∂pj ∂Dj∂pi) = εiθi

The first bracket is εi, which shows the inverse demand elasticity, and the second bracket is θi, which shows the conjectural variation parameter. If the market is a monopoly, θi = 1 and Li = εi; if competition exists in the market, ε = 0 and θi = 0.
We adopt 1 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent and 15 per cent significant levels because the sample size is small.

We note that the estimated R-squares of this study are quite low. This could be because this study does not consider social and regulatory changes related to forestry and forest trade regulations during the analysis period. These changes should be examined in a future paper.
